titleInfo.title: General Order No. 73 from Headquarters District of Tennessee, Nashville

name.namePart: United States -- War Dept -- Adjutant-General's Office

mods.abstract: General order No. 73 from Major General Rousseau sentencing Alfred Fowler of Sumner County to three years hard labor in the penitentiary in Nashville for the crime of "being a bushwhacker" with the Lay & Harper Gang, shooting at Federal Soldiers, plundering, robbing, horse stealing, and damaging unarmed citizens friendly to the United States.
mods.accessCondition: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.

relatedItem.identifier: Page 1 of 2 Head Quarters Dist of Tennessee Nashville Tenn Oct. 29th /64 General Orders) No 73 ) ) Before a Military Commission [missing] [missing] at Gallatin Tennessee pursuant to Special orders No 160. Head Quarters Dist of Tennessee – dated July 9th 1864. And of which Lieut Col. MClain F. Wood 10th Ill. Vet. Volunteers was President – was arraigned and tried. Alfred Fowler of Sumner Co. Tenn. Charge: “Being a Bushwhacker Specification: “In this that the said Alfred Fowler of Sumner Co. Tennessee did sometime in the month of June 1864 or thereabouts join a band of Bushwhackers which is known as “Lay & Harper’s Gang” and that he the said Alfred Fowler – since his connection with said band of Bushwhackers has been skulking through the County of Sumner in the state of Tennessee and adjoining Counties with said band of Bushwhackers whose business it [missing [missing] and now is to Shoot at Soldiers belonging to the Army of the United States, and to Plunder, rob, and damage, unarmed Citizens friendly to the United States” Charge 2nd : “Horse Stealing” Specification: “In this that the said Alfred Fowler of Sumner County Tennessee did at different times and places in the County of Page 2 of 2 Sumner Tenn. And adjoining Counties since his connection with “Lay and Harper’s” band of Bushwhackers, together with said Marauders, take and steal Horses – the personal property of Citizens of said Counties To which Charges and Specifications the accused pleaded Guilty Findings: Of the specifications first charge “Guilty” Of the first charge “Guilty” Of the Specifications second charge “Guilty” Of the second charge “Guilty” Sentence: And the commission does therefore sentence him Alfred Fowler of Sumner County Tenn. to be confined for the term of three years at hard labor in the Penitentiary at Nashville Tenn. or in such other place as may be designated by the proper authority” The proceedings and findings and Sentence in the case of Alfred Fowler of Sumner Co. Tenn. is approved and confirmed. The Provost Marshal of Nashville Tenn. will see the sentence is properly carried into effect. By Command of Maj Gen Rousseau Official (Signed) Thos. C. Williams Signed B. H. Polk A.A.A.G. Assistant Adjutant General. A True Copy E. L. Anderson Capt. Hunter Brooks Post Prv Mar Nashville Tenn Capt and Asst Pro Marshal

titleInfo.title: Record Group 21 Adjutant General's Office Records, 1796-1900

relatedItem.abstract: The images found in this section have been gathered from various manuscript collections and offer a glimpse at the wide variety of material available at the Tennessee State Library and Archives that may be of interest to those researching Civil War history and genealogy. These images illustrate the extensive recordkeeping system at work during the Civil War and demonstrate the complex organizational structure needed to handle the massive accumulation of records. From transportation orders to quartermaster records, these items not only provide insight into the soldiers’ lives, they also illustrate the costs of war and sacrifices that were made from all facets of society on both the Confederate and Federal sides...
